summary: Arvind Remedies Ltd has denied violating India's takeover code after the markets regulator moved the Supreme Court against an exemption allowed to the drug maker from making an open offer.

summary: The catcher is part of a powerful Yankees lineup through its first few games.

headline: Utility Revamps Debt to Aid Survival
summary: Energy Future Holdings Corp. moved to restructure its huge debt load, seeking in one fell swoop to push back the maturity of $22 billion of debt and fend off a legal attack by activist hedge fund Aurelius Capital Management.

summary: Six Hollywood studios on Monday sued Internet-movie company Zediva, saying the start-up violates copyright law with its system for showing new movies online for $1 or $2.

headline: BOJ Considers Quake Response
summary: As Bank of Japan officials eye a new bank-lending program aimed at areas hard hit by disaster, bolder steps to stimulate the broader economy appear to be off the table for the coming policy meeting Wednesday and Thursday.

headline: Asian Currencies Spur Action
summary: Central banks in South Korea, Malaysia and Indonesia appeared to intervene in the foreign-exchange market, continuing the fight to slow the rise in their currencies.

headline: Bobby Cannavale Chats About His 'Hat'
summary: The New Jersey-bred actor talks about why he was drawn to his new role, how Chris Rock is handling the stage, and how he memorizes his lines.

headline: Tip of the Day
summary: Tottenham Hotspurwill be hoping for lightning to strike twice when the English Premier League team travels to Spain to face Real Madrid in the Champions League quarterfinals on Tuesday.

headline: Libyan Oil Minister Says Calls to Oust Gadhafi Unrealistic
summary: Libyan Oil Minister Shukri Ghanem said he supported change in the country but said that calls for Col. Moammar Gadhafi to relinquish power were unrealistic and could lead to a "dangerous" vacuum.

headline: U.S. Lenders Near Pacts in Foreclosure Probe
summary: Fourteen U.S. lenders are on the verge of agreements with federal bank regulators to overhaul their handling of foreclosures and treatment of delinquent borrowers in response to allegations of abuses that emerged last fall.

headline: With Jets Idle, Bears Circle Southwest Airlines
summary: Traders dive into bearish options after learning that the carrier has grounded part of its fleet.

headline: Dow Rises to Highest Close in 34 Months
summary: The session was marked by light trading volume, and other major indexes finished flat as the technology sector sagged.

headline: Sporting Side Effects
summary: None

headline: United Plane Has 'Smoke Issue,' Lands Safely
summary: A United Airlines A320 plane bound for San Francisco from New Orleans early Monday morning turned back minutes after departing, with one of the pilots telling air-traffic controllers "we have a smoke issue," according to an audio account of the air-traffic control back and forth at the airport.

headline: Transocean Regrets 'Insensitive' Wording in Filing
summary: Transocean said it regrets "insensitive" wording in a recent securities filing in which the contract driller called 2010 its "best year in safety performance" despite the Deepwater Horizon disaster.

headline: Photos of the Day
summary: In today's pictures, an Islamist hides during clashes in Bangladesh, a woman worships goddess Durga in India, an Arab-Jewish actor is gunned down and more.

headline: American Airlines Ends Spat With Expedia
summary: American Airlines reached an agreement with online travel agent Expedia to restore the carrier's fares after a dispute kept them off the site for months.

headline: Asia's Banking Bonanza: Resource Deals
summary: Deals involving natural-resource companies helped drive investment-banking revenues for the Asia Pacific region to a record in the first quarter, despite a decline in share sales, another key revenue source.

headline: Detroit Orchestra Strike Nears End
summary: The striking musicians of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra agreed to immediately return to work, increasing the likelihood a tentative contract agreement over pay and benefits will be approved later this week.

headline: SEC Probes Backdoor Mergers
summary: The SEC is investigating the "disturbing trend" of Chinese and other companies registered through backdoor mergers with dormant shell companies.

headline: Legality of Human Gene Patents Questioned
summary: A U.S. federal appeals panel, hearing a case over Myriad Genetics patents for identifying breast- and ovarian-cancer risk, probed whether it makes sense to continue allowing the patenting of human gene sequencing.

headline: British American Tobacco Creates Start-Up
summary: British American Tobacco is creating a start-up company to develop nicotine-based products for smokers seeking a safer alternative to cigarettes.

headline: McDonald's PlansNational 'Hiring Day'
summary: McDonald's is planning a National Hiring Day with the goal of hiring 50,000 new workers...and changing the image of a 'McJob.'

headline: Euro Gives Back Gains on Dollar
summary: The euro's run higher this year on rate-hike hopes appeared to falter as market participants questioned how much more this prospect could boost the single currency.

headline: Turkey Plays Mediator in Libya Crisis
summary: The Libyan regime and leaders of the rebel opposition are each offering proposals on how to reach a cease-fire in the Arab nation's conflict, a Turkish official said Monday, as an envoy from Col. Moammar Gadhafi arrived in Ankara for talks.

headline: Worries on Europe Governance Rules
summary: European executives remain wary of new Europe-wide rules on corporate governance a survey showed Monday, as EU Internal Markets Commissioner Michel Barnier sets out his reform plans.

headline: Proposed Actelion Board Calls for Cuts
summary: One month ahead of a crucial shareholder meeting of Actelion, the proposed new board members sent a letter to investors, calling for cost cuts to restructure Europe's largest biotechnology firm.

headline: Petrobras to Investigate Problem in Gulf Field
summary: Petroleo Brasileiro's U.S. unit said Monday it must fully investigate a problem encountered in a U.S. Gulf of Mexico oil-and-gas development before it can announce a start-up date for the project.

headline: U.S. Makes Pipeline-Safety Push
summary: The U.S. called for tougher regulation of oil and natural gas pipelines to prevent accidents similar to explosions that have killed 14 people in California and Pennsylvania over the past seven months.

headline: EU Slashes ArcelorMittal Antitrust Fine
summary: The European Commission on Monday said it has sharply reduced an antitrust fine levied against steel giant ArcelorMittal for participating in a long-running cartel operated by prestressing steel producers.

headline: With Brent Oil at $120, Economy Becomes a Worry
summary: With expectations that oil prices will continue to rise, the question increasingly is becoming whether this will choke off growth.

headline: Brent Crude Tops $120
summary: Oil futures settled at their highest levels in more than two years, with Brent crude surpassing $120 a barrel, as a drawn-out fight in a Libyan oil town squashed hopes that the conflict might end soon.

headline: Vietnam Sentences Revolutionary Scion
summary: The son of one of Vietnam's prominent Communist revolutionaries was sentenced to seven years in prison for allegedly calling for an end to the country's one-party system.

headline: Asset-Backed Bonds Go Exotic
summary: The hunger for securities backed by such exotic assets as timber harvests and timeshare revenue is growing, even as the broader market for the investments continues to shrink.

headline: Wal-Mart Explores Selling Large Appliances
summary: Wal-Mart Stores may begin adding large appliances such as stoves and dishwashers to stores in Texas this year as part of a pilot program that could lead to a nationwide launch.

headline: Deals Support Stocks in Asia, Europe
summary: Most Asian stock markets gained Monday, with copper miners boosting Australia's main index after China's Minmetals Resources launched a takeover offer for Equinox Minerals. The Stoxx Europe 600 edged up 0.1%, helped by Solvay's deal to buy Rhodia.

headline: Korean Oil Refiners Cut Prices
summary: South Korea's big oil refiners are cutting prices, putting pressure on smaller companies to follow suit as the government pushes to curb inflation.

headline: Japan Bankers Support Tepco
summary: The chairman of the Japanese Bankers Association said that Tokyo Electric Power Co. shouldn't be nationalized but that the government should support it however necessary, and added that the banking industry also will continue to assist the embattled utility.

headline: Minmetals to Bid for Equinox
summary: Minmetals Resources said it intends to make a $6.5 billion offer for copper miner Equinox Minerals, what would be China's biggest takeover bid for an Australian-listed resources company as Beijing pursues deals to guarantee commodity supplies.

headline: Italy Recognizes Libyan Rebels
summary: Italy has recognized the governing body of rebel forces opposed to the regime of Col. Moammar Gadhafi as Libya's sole "legitimate interlocutor," Italian Foreign Minister Franco Frattini said, as Rome seeks a way to reestablish its access to Libyan oil and natural gas.

headline: Delayed WTC Muni Deal Moves Closer to Sale
summary: A $1.275 billion municipal-bond deal to help finance one of the World Trade Center towers could be sold as soon as next week.

headline: Gold, Silver Rise
summary: Gold futures rose and silver hit a fresh 31-year high as investors sought to hedge against the threat of inflation amid rising oil prices.

headline: Analysis Flags Fears Over Avastin
summary: A soon-to-be-published analysis comparing Roche's cancer medicine Avastin and Novartis's eye drug Lucentis in treating an eye disease could fan health concerns over Avastin's off-label use and thus avert a feared slide in Lucentis sales in the U.S.

headline: Japan Debates Food Tariffs and Imports
summary: The disruption to food production in Japan, coupled with the questions about the country's food safety in light of possible radiation contamination, have raised the thorny question as to whether the country should scrap some of its protectionist tariffs on certain products and welcome more imports.

headline: Deal News Supports European Markets
summary: Major European stock indexes closed little changed Monday, as deal news lifted some shares including French chemicals manufacturer Rhodia, while banks were mostly lower as capital worries continued to weigh on the sector.

headline: AMD Affirms Margin Expectations
summary: Advanced Micro Devices affirmed its full-year and long-term margin expectations after announcing changes to a supply agreement with manufacturing partner Globalfoundries.

headline: EU Confident of Court Ruling in Steel-CO2 Case
summary: The European Commission is confident that a European Court will rule in its favor in a case brought by the European steel-industry lobby about the rules on carbon-dioxide emissions.

headline: German Lender Is Asked to Boycott Stress Tests
summary: The economics minister for the German state of Hesse has called on local state-controlled lender Helaba to boycott a pending round of Europe-wide bank stress tests.

headline: German Steel Group Lifts Output Forecast
summary: A German steel-industry association Monday raised its forecast for 2011 German crude-steel production due to continued demand from key customer industries.

headline: France Releases Plane Crash Images
summary: Investigators said Monday they had discovered part of what appears to be an Airbus plane that crashed into the ocean in 2009, killing everyone onboard, the worst crash in Air France's history.

headline: Troops Fire on Yemeni Protesters
summary: Security forces and plainclothes gunmen opened fire on crowds of Yemenis marching through the southern city of Taiz Monday.

headline: Solvay's Cyclical Thinking
summary: Cyclicality is the curse of the chemicals industry. Solvay's $4.84 billion all-cash bid for smaller rival Rhodia checks off a lot of boxes, creating a better balanced combined group. But Solvay won't escape the cycle that easily.

headline: Petraeus: Quran Burning Endangers War Effort
summary: The Quran burning by a Florida church, which sparked three days of rioting in Afghanistan, poses new dangers for the war effort against the Taliban, U.S. Gen. David Petraeus warned.

summary: Markets Data Center: Biggest Price Gainers.

summary: Markets Data Center: Money Flow Leaders.

headline: Swiss Accounting Firms to Get U.S. Oversight
summary: U.S. accounting overseers have reached an agreement with Swiss authorities that will open up Swiss accounting firms to U.S. oversight for the first time.

headline: Deutsche Bank Team Quits to Launch Hedge Fund
summary: A 17-year Deutsche Bank veteran who was instrumental in building its emerging-markets trading business has left the bank with a team of seven traders to launch a hedge fund.

headline: Kingway Parent Intervenes in China Beer Deal
summary: Kingway Brewery Holdings said its parent exercised its right to buy a 21% stake in the company, thwarting a move by rival China Resources to buy the stake valued at $165 million.

headline: Intel Chief Otellini's Got $15.7 Million in 2010
summary: Intel paid CEO Paul Otellini $15.7 million in 2010, up 7.3% from a year earlier as rebounding business demand helped the computer-chip giant report its best annual results ever.

headline: Saab Talks Down Collapse Fears
summary: Executives from Spyker and Saab Automobile sought to calm fears the Swedish auto maker could be at risk financially.

headline: Euro-Zone Factory-Gate Prices Surge
summary: Factory gate prices in the euro zone posted their sharpest annual gain for nearly two-and-a-half years in February, putting further pressure on the European Central Bank to raise interest rates later this week.

headline: Libya Turmoil Hits OPEC Output
summary: Crude production from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries fell steeply in March, as greater output from Saudi Arabia failed to make up for Libya's export halt, a Dow Jones Newswires survey showed.

headline: Jobs Data Underline Spain's Woes
summary: Spanish jobless claims rose again in March, adding to signs of a softening economy amid growing political uncertainty.

headline: BP to Sell Arco for $680 Million
summary: BP said it had agreed to sell its Arco Aluminum unit to a Japanese consortium for $680 million, as it steps up a divestment program to recoup the costs of its Gulf of Mexico oil spill.

headline: Toys 'R' Us Hires Friedman
summary: Toys "R" Us named Neil Friedman, a former Mattel executive, as president of its U.S. business. He will oversee all merchandising, marketing and store operations.

headline: Och-Ziff Funds Gains in March
summary: Och-Ziff Capital Management said its funds recorded gains both in performance and in asset level last month, despite a pullback in the equities market.

headline: Resource-Hungry China Offers Deal Insurance
summary: China's voracious appetite for raw materials has earned it a special place in the hearts of mining company shareholders, but it also offers something else: Insurance against ill-conceived deals.

headline: Insurers Say Proposed EU Rules Are Harmful
summary: Insurance associations in the European Union have submitted a joint letter to EU authorities, warning that the draft of the upcoming Solvency II capital-requirements regime contains parts that are "excessively conservative and prescriptive" and may hurt the industry.

headline: India Plans to Issue Regular Job Data
summary: India plans for the first time to issue periodic data on new jobs created in the economy, underscoring the country's recent attempts to add to a slew of macroeconomic indicators to help policy makers make better-informed decisions.

headline: Ratan Tata Answers Telecom Probe Questions
summary: Ratan Tata, chairman of the Tata group conglomerate, has willingly answered all questions posed by one of the parliamentary committees probing into the allegedly rigged radio-spectrum sale of 2008, the head of the panel, Murali Manohar Joshi, said.

headline: McDonald's to Hire 50,000
summary: McDonald's said the company and its franchisees are looking to hire as many as 50,000 people at U.S. restaurants during an April 19 hiring event.

headline: Landry's CEO Offers to Buy McCormick & Schmick's
summary: Landry's Restaurants founder and Chief Executive Tilman J. Fertitta offered to buy McCormick & Schmick's Seafood Restaurants in a deal valuing the casual-dining company at $137.2 million.

headline: Goldman U.K. Executive to Quit
summary: Goldman Sachs Group's head of U.K. investment banking is leaving the firm and expected to join a new investment firm that former BP Chief Executive Tony Hayward is starting, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: Apax Buys Software Firms
summary: Apax Partners is buying two software makers, Epicor Software and Activant Solutions, for about $2 billion, with plans to combine them.

headline: Global Chip Sales Fall
summary: None

headline: Yuan REIT Aims for $1.8 Billion in Hong Kong IPO
summary: Cheung Kong Holdings's yuan-denominated real estate investment trust plans to raise $1.53 billion to $1.83 billion in an IPO ahead of its listing in Hong Kong.

headline: CME, ICE Trading Volumes Rise
summary: CME Group and IntercontinentalExchange reported surging trading volumes for March from a year ago and for all of the first quarter.

headline: Deal News Drives Sydney
summary: Most Asian markets clinched gains, with copper miners boosting Australian shares after China's Minmetals Resources made a takeover bid for Equinox Minerals, while Japanese exporters were supported by a weaker yen.

headline: Bharat Heavy Expects Sales to Hit $11 Billion
summary: Bharat Heavy Electricals' fiscal year revenue is likely to reach $11 billion on the back of its large order book and a rise in new order inflows, the chairman of India's largest power equipment manufacturer by sales said.

headline: Japanese Yields Rise
summary: Investors were cautious ahead of Tuesday's auction of 10-year  government bonds.

headline: Earthquake Shakes Buildings in Delhi
summary: An earthquake was felt in central Delhi just after 5 p.m. local time Monday.

headline: The Arab Revolt and American Interests
summary: A U.S. strategy has to begin by distinguishing between friends and enemies.

headline: GAIL to Form Joint Venture In Vadodara
summary: GAIL (India) is forming a joint venture to set up a gas distribution network in the western Indian city of Vadodara.

headline: India Shares End Higher
summary: Indian shares recovered strongly after a dip in the previous session as foreign funds hunted for bargains, mainly in mid-cap and small-cap companies, with the day's gains being led by technology and banks.

headline: GE's Immelt Defends Nuclear Industry
summary: The head of General Electric, which manufactured some of the nuclear reactors at Japan's stricken Fukushima Daiichi plant, said the nuclear industry has had a "safe track record."

headline: Chinese Authorities Detain Outspoken Artist
summary: Chinese officials detained Ai Weiwei, one of China's most famous contemporary artists, as he tried to board a flight from Beijing to Hong Kong, making him the latest victim of a sustained clampdown on dissent that is raising concern among many Western governments.

headline: Idea Cellular to Appeal Stay On Spice Merger
summary: Idea Cellular is in the process of filing an application to the Delhi High Court to vacate the ex-parte stay on its merger with Spice Communications.

headline: Electrosteel, Dart Energy Form Joint Venture
summary: Electrosteel Castings said it has entered into a joint venture with Australia's Dart Energy to extract gas from its Parbatpur coal mine in eastern India.

headline: Gates Will Urge Europe to Maintain Aid
summary: Bill Gates visits several European cities next week in an effort to persuade Europeans not to cut aid budgets in the face of austerityâ€”and in particular not to reduce spending on vaccinations and agriculture.

headline: Vedanta Aluminium Likely to Issue Coal Tender
summary: Vedanta Aluminium, a unit of London-listed Vedanta Resources, is likely to issue a tender Tuesday to source 10 million metric tons of coal to feed its growing operations, a person familiar with the development said.

headline: Maran's Co. Pledges Shares in SpiceJet
summary: SpiceJet said KAL Airways, the controlling shareholder in the Indian airline, has pledged 38.43% of its holding in the low-fare carrier. KAL Airways is owned by media baron and Sun TV Network Ltd founder Kalanithi Maran.

headline: Treasury Market Braces for Higher Interest Rates
summary: While Federal Reserve officials openly feud over the right time to begin tightening monetary policy, Treasury investors are starting to lean with the hawks.

headline: India Aims for Steel Capacity Jump
summary: India will expand its steel production capacity by around 15%, or 12 million metric tons, this year to meet rising demand from infrastructure and automobile sectors, said federal Steel Secretary P.K. Misra.

headline: Hindusthan Glass Set to Buy Foreign Maker
summary: Hindusthan National Glass and Industries is likely to pay between two billion and four billion rupees for the target company.

headline: Powering Down in Japan
summary: Japan relies heavily on nuclear plants to meet baseload electricity demand. In the event of a hot summer, there may only be enough power to supply three-quarters of demand. Shortfalls could last years.

headline: Zambia May Drop Chinese Shooting Case
summary: Zambia's prosecutors want to halt proceedings against two Chinese mine supervisors accused of shooting at least 13 Zambian miners during a wage protest in October.

headline: Hong Kong Expedites Visas for Expats in Japan
summary: Hong Kong officials have taken special measures to speed up approval of 270 one-year work visas for professionals looking to leave Japan after the March 11 earthquake and tsunami, a move aimed primarily at attracting and retaining top talent in the finance industry.

headline: Shamsher M. Chowdhury: Bangladesh Goes Backward
summary: Dhaka's persecution of microfinance pioneer Mohammad Yunus reflects a larger problem with Bangladesh's democracy.

headline: Woolworths CEO Luscombe to Retire
summary: Woolworths Chief Executive Michael Luscombe is ending a five-year tenure at the helm of Australia's biggest retailer.

headline: Week Ahead: Companies Seek Cash Abroad
summary: In recent months, the 2G scam and other evidence of rampant corruption and graft in India Inc. have turned foreign investors and companies cautious, and the Indian stock markets negative. As a result, Indian companies are looking at various options to raise cash including listing abroad.

summary: The top business leaders in Asia making headlines last week in select global and regional media. Powered by Dow Jones Factiva and edited for relevance and clarity.

headline: Morning News Roundup
summary: Here is a roundup of news from Indian newspapers, news wires and Web sites on Monday, April 4, 2011. Deals India has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

headline: In White Plains, a School Faces Cries of Non!
summary: People in White Plains are trying to block plans by the private French-American School of New York to build a $60 million campus on the site of a recently shuttered country club.

headline: Brownstone Neighbors Ajar
summary: The architect who designed the condo development being completed at Fifth Avenue and St. Johns Place in Park Slope, scoffs at those who would say that new buildings in historic neighborhoods should mimic their designs.

headline: It's Hard to Hit Shots in Front of 75,000
summary: Since the NCAA started holding Final Fours exclusively in stadiums in 1997, the shooting at college basketball's premier event has been sub-optimal.

headline: Tankan Results Show Dimmer Outlook
summary: Japanese companies were more pessimistic about business conditions in the three months ahead following the massive earthquake and tsunami that struck northeast Japan in March.

headline: Beyond the EU Policy Makers' Dream
summary: Let's do a thought experiment: assume that all goes as planned by euro-zone policy makers...

headline: A Baby Shower for Moms in Need
summary: Janice Weinman is throwing Newark mothers one big baby shower. Three-hundred mothers and mothers-to-be will receive essential baby items from the New York-based nonprofit Kids in Distressed Situations.

headline: Disaster Highlights Component Firms
summary: As companies scramble to fill holes in their supply chains opened by the disaster in Japan, component distributors such as Fusion Trade are in high demand.

headline: (Non)Binding Arbitration
summary: Disputes between investors and brokerages are handled by arbitrators. But their rulings aren't always the end of the line, as illustrated by cases involving "Dallas" actor Larry Hagman and retired basketball player Horace Grant.

headline: Rangers 3, Flyers 2
summary: Wojtek Wolski's shootout goal lifted the Rangers to a victory over the Philadelphia Flyers on Sunday.

headline: The Nuclear Ides Have Come, but Not Passed
summary: Regarding George Monbiot's quote in "Notable and Quotable" (March 23): If immediate death is not the result of a radiation event, then the event must be benign and long-term consequences have no importance.

headline: What's News
summary: Here are the top business stories from today's Wall Street Journal Asia.

headline: Christie Loses Redistrict Fight
summary: Democrats in New Jersey have a better shot at retaining a majority in Trenton this November after winning a once-in-a-decade fight to redraw legislative districts.

headline: Behind Ping An's Odd Deal
summary: Ping An Insurance's recent decision to raise $2.5 billion by selling shares to one of Hong Kong's wealthiest businessmen has raised questions about fairness. It also may illustrate the power of unintended consequences.

headline: Workers Fail to Plug Leak at Reactor
summary: Workers failed to plug a cracked chamber leaking radioactive water from a stricken Japanese nuclear-power plant. Separately, the plant operator discovered the bodies of two workers missing since the March 11 earthquake.

headline: World Watch
summary: Here is a selection of news from around the world from today's Wall Street Journal Europe.

headline: Jobs and Wages
summary: The recovery gains steam, but wages are stagnant.

headline: Immigration Lessons From English Soccer
summary: The Premier League is a testament to what happens when barriers are broken down and a market attracts the most talented people around the world.

headline: Sales Look Likely to Have Little Spring
summary: A later Easter holiday and chilled shopper enthusiasm are expected to produce the first monthly drop in same-store sales since August 2009.

headline: Fine Feathered Friends
summary: Thousands of combatants gathered in Union Square to mark International Pillow Fight Day.

headline: Company Sites Beat Job Boards
summary: To make one hire, recruiters wade through more than six times as many applications from job boards than they do from their own websites.

headline: Gains Amid the Worries
summary: Despite concerns about the Middle East and Japan, U.S.-stock funds rose 6.2% in the first quarter of this year and attracted net new money from investors for the first time in nearly two years

headline: Breach at Epsilon Exposes Emails
summary: A data breach at one of the world's largest providers of marketing-email services may have enabled unauthorized people to access the names and email addresses for customers of major financial-services, retailing and other companies.

headline: Two Perspectives on Teaching School
summary: Jason L. Riley's "The Weekend Interview With Randi Weingarten" (March 26) is truly frightening. Laying off teachers by seniority is "the best mechanism we have." Sure it is, if all you care about is protecting the mediocre teacher and preserving the status quo.

headline: U.S. Freezes Arms Delivery to Lebanon
summary: The U.S. has quietly frozen weapon shipments to Lebanon's armed forces following the collapse of the country's pro-Western government in January, underlining growing concerns about Hezbollah's role there.

headline: Rumsfeld: Know the Unknowns
summary: INFORMATION AGE: If his document-enhanced digital autobiography becomes a model, we'll know more about how decisions are made.

headline: Coaching Urged for Executive Women
summary: Inadequate career development has kept women from reaching the top ranks of the corporate ladder, according to a report set to be released Tuesday by  management consulting firm McKinsey.

headline: British MC's New Musical Mix: Gentlemanly 'Chap-Hop'
summary: For some British rappers, nothing goes better with laying down rhymes than a gin and tonic and a Sunday afternoon stroll.

headline: Unserious on Iran Sanctions
summary: The Obama team picks on a small fry, ignoring Chinese titans.

headline: BP Seeks to Resume Drilling in the Gulf
summary: BP is seeking permits to resume drilling in the Gulf of Mexico this summer, some 15 months after the Deepwater Horizon disaster.

headline: Libya Rebels Tap Army Defectors
summary: Defected Libyan military commanders and their units are taking the lead in the fight against forces loyal to Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi, in a rebel bid to stanch setbacks on the front lines and facilitate greater cooperation with coalition forces.

headline: Four Killed as Gulfstream Jet Crashes
summary: A Gulfstream Aerospace business jet undergoing flight tests in Roswell, N.M., crashed and burst into flames, killing the four people aboard.

headline: Small Lenders Banked on Fed
summary: Small banks were the most frequent users of the Federal Reserve's discount window during a 14-month period in 2008 and 2009, among them seven units of an Illinois bank-holding company that turned to the emergency-lending facility a total of 330 times before they failed.

headline: Cause Unknown in Southwest Jet's Rupture
summary: Officials haven't pinpointed the cause of a five-foot gash that opened in the fuselage of a Southwest Airlines jet, and the carrier said that it expects many of its oldest Boeing 737s to remain grounded for inspections.

headline: Lights Out for Mall Tenant
summary: After 20 years of operation, the Kmart in North Plainfield, N.J. closed its doors for good, the latest victim of the economic downturn and a major headache for this borough of 22,000 residents.
